text:
I love seeing Gura improve at monster hunter and fight new monsters, reminds me back in the old days of when I was playing Monster Hunter Freedom Unite on my PSP, and using Hammer ahaha. 

I do have some nice advice for you gura that will help you improve hammer skills:
1. If you use the normal attack, you can do a double slam followed by a golf swing that does a lot of damage, I believe with the switch the button is the X button, but I could be wrong. This is your bread and butter combo and is faster then the wire bug slam you do. You can also do a chain of stationary slams that combo into a huge slam, with the y button I believe. This track is great but should only be used to punish the monster when it is down.

2. Paralysis hammers are VERY GOOD. If there is a paralysis hammer, get it, it leaves the monster frozen for a short amount of time and lets you bonk it a lot. Also I recommend using a raw damage hammer like you have been because you can use it on any hunt, rather then switching the element and learning what monsters are weak to.

Lastly, I love how you are trying to increase your hunter rank, but you should probably start on the village hub with Hinoa first. The hunters hub is soloable, along with everything else in the game, but the hub monsters have a good portion more of hp, and it would be wise to do hub to get the best monster parts and weapons you can, then come back to the hunters hub to fight the harder monsters, because you are fast approaching the hunting hub magnamalo quest, andd he will be very very hard to solo with your current armor and weapons, not impossible, but very very hard and stressful.

Anyways, happy hunting, and I look forward to you become a master hunter!!!
author: @Omegez1

text:
I'd like to leave a suggestion that the next time you play Rise off stream you take a walk around Kamura village and check out it's facilities and what they can do for you. For example you can recruit extra Palamutes and Palicos in the buddy plaza which you can send on missions for monster materials or to gather herbs and bugs and stuff to make it easier for you to craft traps by giving you a steady supply of materials. 
Also I think someone mentioned item loadouts in chat at one point. From the item chest you can make an item loadout with pre-selected items you want with you on a mission. So when you come back from a quest you can simply go to your item chest, click on that item loadout and have your inventory restocked with whatever traps and potions you want and have already made.
author: @Druidlover

text:
while hammer's inputs are pretty easy, its still moderately difficult nowing WHEN to commit to each combo or big move. its not charge-blade or gunlance hard, but still takes time to learn. you're definitely getting there though. 

the only weapons i'd say are EASY are the bowguns and the longsword. bowguns are super safe because you're far away from all the stabby chompy stuff and pretty much just point n shoot. longsword is full on baby mode. its damage is solid and extremely easy to pull off, its quick, its inputs are simple and its counter move has a ridiculous window making it dumb easy to land. i still use it, its a FUN weapon, but not a hard one lol

text:
PIXELATED  THUMBNAIL FIX:

Sorry for caps, just wanted to make sure you see this (hopefully)--

Streamlabs has been re-uploading a low-rez version of my thumbnails recently too, I fixed it by deleting the preview thumbnail just before streaming in the "go live" menu, and uploading the thumbnail from the streaming software itself

idk if you use streamlabs but that's what I found fixed the issue, somewhere along the line a low-rez version of the thumbnail is copied over the full resolution one when actually going live and uploading the thumbnail /in/ streamlabs makes sure the full resolution thumbnail is still there when live

If you don't use streamlabs then idk, probably is a youtube issue but afaik it's a bug with streamlabs if that's what you use to stream, hope that helps~!

text:
On the topic of Hammer being "too easy," the truth is that, after a certain amount of experience, no weapon type really makes hunts generally easier than another. Weapons that are "beginner-friendly" just have less moving parts that you have to master to get reliable results, and let you focus on getting a grasp of the fundamentals of Monster Hunter combat at the same time. The more advanced weapons do not add extra mechanics to make hunts harder or to end up with far more damage output; they do so to make them more unique and offer their own type of fun. Once you get to the point of trying for optimal hunts(as in, not number-crunching level optimal, but slamming the monster in its weak spots more consistently level optimal), Hammer and Charge Blade end up having just as much depth to them.
As someone who's sinked hundreds of hunts into each weapon type, no one, beginner or not, should feel guilty about their choice of weapons. Unless you run Kelbi Bow in 3U. Then you should feel at least a bit guilty about what you're doing to the monsters.

text: I had to leave the stream early so I missed a lot. But I saw someone say you were worried about hammer being too easy. It‚Äôs not too easy. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs average difficulty. Also, learning to fight all the different monsters is a bigger part of the challenge than the weapon you use, the deeper you get in the game. The charge blade is far from a beginners weapon. And while nothing can match the superior power of the greatsword, any weapon that makes you feel powerful is a good choice. Greater challenge will come with progression. I like bagelboose.

author: @DusKTheStray

text:
Some tips for someone completely new to Monster hunter mechanics (correct me if im wrong):

-The first damage you deal to a sleeping monster is doubled. 
-Rolling on ground will put out your fire debuff.
-Getting knocked down around 3 times in a short period of time will stun you.
-Holding direction buttons while attacking will have different moveset for most weapon
-Traps can be used to trap them and get free hits instead of capturing them. (you can bring their materials so you can craft it even when you are outside of your tent)
-Different weapons have different effectiveness against different part of every monster have  

-Running towards the opposite direction of the monster you are facing and dodge will allow you to do a dive-evade, where the i-frame is a lot longer than other dodge, you can use it to dodge almost everything if you time it decent enough.

-Talk to npc when they have blue/yellow chat box, they give lots of optional quest and unlockables, other than the online cat npc, all the other npc don't show personal information so don't worry about that, if you do, do it offstream first lol.

text:
Amazing stream Gura! :_GuraAA:
I had a quick tip about inventory stuff. MonHun makes inventory management super simple with just a tiny bit of prep. You only have to prepare your item pouch ONCE! Then you register it as an item loadout. Then before every quest, pick the registered loadout. Your inventory is automatically fixed and everything else goes to the item box.

Another tip about the item box: If you auto sort, you only have to care about the stuff on the first page. Everything past that is crafting materials.

author: @darkraiz

text:
Nice hunting! You are getting better! Saw lots of good rounds!
I like that you noticed Rathian was clumsy, thats a good step to finding monster openings and checking their patterns. I would suggest dodging a monster to the side over moving away( depends on position, sometimes you can even roll forward to escape and counter quickly), if you are closer, you can take advantage of moves with huge lag like a fire ball for example. If you are far, you have to run to it first, so maybe only one strike then opening is gone.

Its a good idea to stay at green sharpness over yellow. On paper, green is 5% more damage, but if you factor the hidden mechanics, its a bigger difference than that. You type Monster hunter rise Yellow sharpness in the youtube search bar and choose the 3 min video by gaijin. If a strike lands at the end or too near the start of the animation, there is a 30% to 40% power loss. Burst dmg moves really feel this loss when it happens. Its a hidden mechanic for yellow and below sharpness.

Tip for sleep status, the first hit that wakes up a monster does double damage. If you use impact crater, try to make the first one, the strike while jumping, miss, since its not strong.

author: @ianc1331

text:
Don't take this as back seating, feel free to ignore my advice but there's a lot you're not doing or realizing and it just makes it harder on yourself.

1. Sorry to tell you this but the real game doesn't start until after you defeat Magnamalo. You're still on baby mode.. 
2. Speak to everyone in the village with a speech bubble because you're missing a lot of things by not talking to them (new weapons, wirebug skills, Great wirebugs). 
3. Also look for the Cohoot nest for the Lagniapples (google it) The nest fills up max after every 5 missions I think so if you're not collecting, you're just losing out on items. And hire more Palicos and Palamutes to train and send on missions (use the Lagniapples for better results). By not doing these things, you're really setting yourself up for misery later or A WHOLE LOT of farming and the game will really not be fun.
4. Use the Argosy to farm God beetles and Bitter Bugs (you need more Palicos and Palamutes). You really need to learn the crafting menu and what these things do.
4. Are you doing the optional quests? they're quests that can just be completed passively as you play the game and are repeatable and give you armor spheres which lets you upgrade your armor for better defense. Again, by not doing these, you're really doing yourself any favors at all.
5. Don't ignore urgent quests (That's how you rank up) and unfortunately rampage quests are somewhat necessary, please consider going online either with members or randos to complete it, it'll make your life easier.
6. Learn wirebug evade ZL+B when you get knocked down. You can zip away fast and you WILL need it when you start facing very fast, aggressive monsters. No, you haven't met them yet..
7. Learn to utilize Stinkminks (The white cat things). Use them, run at a monster until it smells you and bait them towards your target and let them fight.
8. If using hammer, once the monster gets knocked down, use the A,A,A,A,A combo to deal a lot of damage.
9. Press + and press R1 until you see Hunter's Notes, It tells you the monsters weaknesses. Some monsters are weak to fire, ice, blunt damage (hammer), blade or ammo....very useful.. You don't have to "main" anything, you can Use Hammer, Charge Blade and a ranged weapon to mix things up.
10. Find the Sub camps on each map and do the quest associated with them so you can fast travel to each location and get around A LOT faster and set down the great wirebugs.

If you don't plan on playing past Magnamalo or a certain point then disregard my advice but if you plan on playing for higher ranks, you REALLY need to do these things. Or again, you're just going to be in a world of hurt and the game really won't be fun. It starts to become very unforgiving.

text:
Some things to add.
1. Charge Blade ZL+A is a counter. If you get hit during this, you will gain 5 full loaded phials and are given the opportunity to X+A to saed or X to charge sword.
2. Go into settings and turn on player outline so you can see yourself inside of large monsters that block your view. Also zoom your camera range out.
3. Make a loadout so you can quickly restock potions or traps before a hunt.
4. ZL to sprint on doggo.
5. Set up the radial menu to quickly select items and use them.
6. Do village quests to rank up. You'll be given tests that will raise your hunter rank up to HR4.
7. Try all weapons. They're all fun and all play differently.

text:
Next time you play Minecraft, can you make a grave for Bowson? :_GuraCry:

And I hope you don't mind some general advice, but you don't only want to do your biggest, slowest attacks. I know you're lazy you like to learn by doing, but I really recommend watching video tutorials for every weapon you're interested in. You also want to study the monsters movements and attack when they leave themselves open.
It's not a game you can brute force like DMC because it doesn't have an easy mode. It starts off easy, but gets gradually harder.

text:
Dude Gura, I promise you have nothing to worry about feeling like Hammer is "too easy." There is so so much depth and stuff to learn with EVERY weapon, but you can also just pick up and go "haha bonk" way easier with some weapons right away. Have fun with it and learn when you feel ready!

By the way, I feel like you were in a pretty good mood today. I hope that was actually the case, and you weren't just loopy from sleep deprivation or anything. Get you some food and medicine maybe so you feel better. See you soon Gura! <3

author: @Clain_1337

text:
¬†@Clain_1337¬† Bowgun needs to know ammo types and which to bring for what monster, the critical ranges of each ammo, what the hitzones are like of monsters, LBG has to know how to slide dodge, how to get the most explosions out of their mines, HBG has to know how to dodge attacks despite being a WALKING CANNON (with a shield if you're a coward), when to counter and when to shoulder check through attacks, when to charge shots vs when to just shoot, when to use special ammo. Longsword needs to know what openings are long enough to do spirit combos, its actually good damage moves have incredibly narrow hitboxes, it has the only counter in the game that's actually  remotely difficult to time in Iai Spirit Slash, and has to manage their sword gauge. Dual blades need stamina management, moveset knowledge of how to hit monster weakspots that are high out of range, knowing when you can fit in super long uncancelable combos, when you can use Archdemon attacks for more damage than Demon mode, where to use Piercing Bind and how to get the most hits out of it, more sharpness management than most any other weapon, and more in depth understanding of elements and elemental hitzones than any other weapon.

EVERY. Weapon. Has depth. Again, just because some are easier to pick up and bonk a monster with doesn't change that.
